awd_titl_txt: Industrial Controls and Telematics Across Disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
Morgan Community College will develop an Industrial Controls and Telematics (ICT) certificate to provide access to high-tech and high-wage employment opportunities for a diverse rural region in Colorado. This will bring modern practices of telematics and industrial controls into the current precision agriculture and industrial maintenance technician programs. This will help meet local workforce needs in a rapidly emerging technology field. Often employees gain knowledge of ICT through on-the-job training, however, industry states that having this knowledge as employees on-board is imperative in today's technical fields. The ICT certificate will also add rigorous STEM content to courses in telematics. This will ensure a greater number of students are entering the high-performance workplace with enhanced STEM theoretical understanding, technical skills, and relevant competencies.

Telematics data can be leveraged in an array of challenges particularly through remote and mobile equipment. Management and tracking of assets though telematics enables both remote monitoring and predictive maintenance. This capability is a hallmark of the computerization of manufacturing, also known as Industry 4.0. As smart machines and sensors are used for manufacturing and agricultural environments, processes will become more data-driven and data-enabled. This emerging field is projected to save industry up to 50% of maintenance costs by 2022 through the prevention of asset failure, improvement of asset performance, and lower downtime of automation and process machinery. Having employees with the knowledge of industrial controls, programmable logic controllers, principles of relay logic, workflows, automation systems, and the ability to troubleshoot will help industry minimize downtime and maximize returns. It will also address the gap of the expected annual growth rate of this emerging field by providing a knowledgeable and well-prepared workforce that will bring regional industry and agricultural partners up-to-date with current technology to be competitive in a rapidly evolving and technology-driven global economy.

This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Award Title: Industrial Controls and Telematics (ICT) Across Disciplines

Director/PI:        John Prouty

Federal Award ID: 1902290

 

In 2019, Morgan Community College (MCC) was awarded a Small Grant for Institutions New to the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Program to develop an Industrial Controls and Telematics (ICT) Certificate Program.

Telematics and controls are becoming much more prevalent in many different industries and are sustainable with the shrinking workforce; however, there is a significant need to develop a workforce trained to work within automation and this is where the ICT program was developed to focus on the need to develop a workforce of technicians, trained in working with automation in industries across disciplines.

Robotics has had a significant impact on the manufacturing industry, altering the way products are designed, produced, and assembled. From increased efficiency and productivity to improved safety and quality control, the use of robotics in manufacturing has numerous benefits.

One of the main benefits of robotics in manufacturing is increased efficiency. Robots can work 24/7 without breaks or the need for rest, resulting in a significant increase in production output. They also can perform repetitive tasks with greater accuracy and consistency, resulting in a reduction in errors and waste. This increased efficiency translates into lower production costs, which can ultimately benefit consumers through lower prices.

The Industrial Controls and Telematics (ICT) program was proposed to address many of these emerging technologies in industry. The need for a strong and skilled workforce in the area of maintaining this automation was needed as these are technical systems requiring technical repair. Morgan Community College successfully launched the ICT program in the fall of 2021 and began working with students to develop a strong workforce to meet industry needs in the field of automation. These efforts continue as automation will continue to play a bigger role in continued manufacturing and production with the shrinking workforce.
